QuikDel: A Novel & Scalable Distributed Approach for Efficient Long-haul Delivery

Reinforcement Learning-Based Last-Mile Delivery Framework
Research Team:
Md Nahid Hasan, Vaskar Raychoudhury, Robert Kilgore, Yusuf Ozdemir, Ashman Mehra, Snehanshu Saha
Miami University & BITS Pilani K. K. Birla Goa Campus

Executive Summary

QuikDel is a socially aware, distributed delivery framework that uses reinforcement learning to optimize last-mile logistics at urban scale. The system reduces travel distance by up to 13% over point-to-point baselines while maintaining strong delivery performance and low computational overhead.

13%
Distance Reduction
4 Cities
Tested & Validated
13,866
Deliveries Processed/Hour
99%+
QCense Accuracy

Problem Statement

The COVID-19 pandemic exposed critical limitations in traditional centralized delivery networks. The global Online Food Delivery (OFD) market, valued at $221.65 billion in 2022, is expected to exceed $440 billion by 2030. However, existing systems face fundamental challenges:

  • Traditional routing methods (Dijkstra's, Floyd-Warshall) fail under dynamic, real-time demands
  • Centralized approaches struggle with exponential complexity at city scale
  • Systems often ignore social structures, creating blind spots in underserved communities
  • Previous RL-based approaches like DeliverAI cannot scale beyond small regions

Key Innovations

1. Centralized Training, Decentralized Execution (CTDE)

Agents are trained offline using Q-learning, eliminating online computational overhead. This enables real-time decision-making with minimal system latency, making QuikDel suitable for resource-constrained edge devices.

2. Hierarchical Graph Construction

Urban delivery areas are modeled as a two-layered network of hotspots and superspots, drastically reducing the size of action and state spaces compared to fully connected city-wide networks.

3. QCense: Automated Data Extraction Tool

Open-source tool enabling automatic extraction of city-specific data including census tract boundaries, road networks, and producer-consumer locations. Achieves 99.75% recall and 92.58% precision against official data.

4. Dynamic Ride-Sharing and Load Balancing

Coordinates between agents through prioritized Q-value sharing, supporting dynamic path-sharing and vehicle consolidation without significantly increasing delivery times.

5. Human-Centered Network Design

Explicitly incorporates social structure by accounting for population density, consumer-producer concentration, and high-traffic zones based on real demographic and geographic data.

Methodology

System Architecture

Phase 1: Data Collection & Processing (QCense)

  • Extracts census tract geometries from U.S. Census Bureau
  • Identifies consumer/producer locations via OpenStreetMap
  • Generates distance/time matrices using GraphHopper routing engine

Phase 2: Network Construction

  • Places hotspots at centroids of consumer/producer clusters within census tracts
  • Selects superspots using Superspot Eligibility Score (SES) based on producer/consumer density and connectivity
  • Ensures spatial balance through spacing-aware selection algorithm

Phase 3: Agent Training

  • Trains hotspot-level agents (Mh) for intra-cluster navigation
  • Trains superspot-level agents (Ms) for inter-cluster routing
  • Uses Q-learning with Boltzmann exploration (10,000 episodes per agent)

Phase 4: Decentralized Execution

  • Agents coordinate through request-response mechanism for ride-sharing
  • Deliveries share paths when Preferred Action Sets (PAS) intersect
  • No centralized control required during operation

Experimental Results

Performance Across Major Cities

City Census Tracts Ratio Distance Reduction vs P2P Success Rate
Columbus 278 1:10 0.73% 96%
Philadelphia 423 1:10 7.04% 92%
Chicago 863 1:10 8.03% 94%
New York City 2,190 1:10 5.12% 93%
Chicago Subset 31 1:10 16.85% 95%

Key Findings

  • Distance Savings: QuikDel reduces total distance by an average of 6.62% compared to point-to-point routing and 13.01% compared to ablation study (no ride-sharing)
  • Scalability: In Chicago, QuikDel reduces model complexity from 627.7 million parameters (DeliverAI) to just 377,500 parameters
  • Computational Efficiency: Training time per episode reduced significantly due to multi-fold reduction in state and action space
  • Trade-offs: Average delivery time increases by approximately 348 seconds (32.9%) compared to direct routing, but distances below 35 minutes remain acceptable

Complexity Analysis: QuikDel vs DeliverAI

Component DeliverAI QuikDel
Space - Q-tables Θ(H³) O(H³s)
Time - Agent Training O(H · EDA · tDA) O((Hs + hm) · EQD · tQD)
Time - Agent Interaction O(H) O(hm) or O(Hs)
Scalability Limited to ~31 tracts Tested up to 2,190 tracts

Note: H = total hotspots, Hs = superspots, hm = max hotspots per cluster, tQD <<< tDA

Technical Contributions

Mathematical Framework

QuikDel formulates urban delivery as a Dynamic Multi-Objective Optimization Problem (DMOOP) with three primary objectives:

  • O1: Minimize total distance traveled by all delivery vehicles
  • O2: Minimize average delivery time
  • O3: Minimize total number of active vehicles required

Superspot Eligibility Score (SES)

Novel scoring system that balances producer/consumer density with network connectivity to select optimal superspots. Ensures even spatial distribution while maximizing logistical efficiency.

Preferred Action Set (PAS)

Dynamic coordination mechanism enabling ride-sharing between deliveries. Routes merge when PAS intersects and decouple when paths diverge, optimizing shared segments without sacrificing individual delivery requirements.

Validation & Real-World Impact

QCense Validation (Chicago Dataset)

  • Recall: 99.75% - captures nearly all relevant census tracts
  • Precision: 92.58% - minimal over-selection
  • F1 Score: 96.03% - excellent balance

Simulation Realism

  • Used real traffic data from March 30, 2023 (6:00-7:00 PM peak hours)
  • Bimodal Gaussian distribution models realistic demand peaks
  • Dynamic time limits based on actual travel distances (1.5× base time)
  • Processed 13,866 randomly distributed orders per simulation

Practical Deployment Advantages

  • Fault tolerance through decentralized decision-making (no single point of failure)
  • Rapid retraining capability for changing urban conditions
  • Low memory footprint enables deployment on edge devices
  • Open-source tools facilitate adoption across any U.S. city

Future Work & Extensions

  • Multi-delivery vehicles: Extend beyond 2-delivery limit per vehicle to increase capacity in high-density zones
  • Dynamic superspot clustering: Allow multiple superspots per cluster and adaptive reconfiguration
  • Advanced RL techniques: Explore Deep Q-Networks (DQN) or Actor-Critic models for enhanced adaptability
  • Multi-route ranking: Generate multiple alternative routes rather than single best path
  • Real-time adaptation: Incorporate live traffic, weather, and demand pattern updates
  • International deployment: Extend QCense to support census systems beyond the United States
